bibl.title: Letters from George Miller Sternberg to James Daly and Walter Reed, January 8, 1901

div1.p: Sternberg writes about the importance of scientific investigation. Sternberg orders Reed to return to Washington. He also discusses Carroll's planned promotion and the necessity of Carroll's continued assignment in Cuba.

div1.head: Letters from George Miller Sternberg to James Daly and Walter Reed, January 8, 1901
div1.opener:
January 8, 1901.
Mr. James Daly,
Sec'y Entertainment Committee,
411 Robert Street, St. Paul, Minn.
Dear Sir:-
div1.p:
The most promising sign of the times
at the dawn of the new century is the gen-
eral appreciation among educated people of
the fact that the theories and traditions
of the past must be abandoned in so far as
they conflict with the demonstrations of sci-
ence, and that opinions and assertions made
by the most distinguished men have little
value as compared with the exact knowledge
which has been obtained as the result of ex-
periment and investigation.

div1.head: Letter from George Miller Sternberg to Walter Reed
div1.opener:
January 8, 1901.
Major Walter Reed,
Surgeon U. S. A.,
Columbia Barracks, Cuba,
My dear Doctor:-
div1.p:
I have received your letter of Jan-
uary 1st and will ask to have you ordered
back to Washington immediately after the ad-
journment of the Pan-American Congress.

Will it not be best for Carroll to
stay for awhile? It is my intention to rec-
ommend him for the position of Major and Sur-
geon U.S.Vols., as soon as a vacancy occurs;
but I could not very well do this if he were
on duty in Washington. Please mention this
matter to him and let me know what he thinks
about it.
